185538638.review:
I really like it.
Although it might look very similar to Smash Bros, it certainly don't feel like a smash clone.

I enjoy the pixel art animations and how technical they can be. They really help you understand the core gamplay of a platform fighting game by letting you understanding timing of frames. Also the tutorials, albeit difficult, are a great way to help you understand both the general mechanics of the game and the in-depth moveset of every character.

That's right, because the selling point of this game resides in the diversity of how each character feels. Everyone of them feels unique thanks to a wide range of different moves. I really like the fact that this game brings IDEAS to the genre. There's the tanky character which can recover itself by creating pillars underneath itself, the flanky one that can hang up at distance to an enemy it has previously marked etc.

Also I wanna point out that there's a pletora of game modes that really help the game feel complete, at the same level of the leading figure of the genre.

Overall I think this is a really well crafted fighting game and the developers' passion is visible, if you're interested to the genre you should definitely try it. Unfortunately it's a hidden gem so you won't find much people casually play online (You can still join a community though) :(.

184962202.review:
Quick Review: 
Im gonna be honest with you all, the base game is good enough for a fighting game, it even shines where others don't. Characters are good, the story mode is ok, maps are decent, and DLC content is fine. But this game wouldn't be where it currently is without its workshop support, this, has truly brought the best out of this above average game.

Imagine Ronald McDonald fighting Mario in Xen. No? Well, you're lucky, this game can do exactly that and more. There are endless possibilities and ways you can mix-match characters and stages to make a fight unique and outstanding.

I don't have enough words for this game, just, play it, download whatever you like and give it a go. You'll have fun.

Quick Score: 7.5/10

183872994.review: One of the best fighting games I've ever played. If you want to play a game similar to Smash Bros that still feels unique and that you can play with your friends without needing to either be in person together or pay for a subscription, this is for you. The vast modding scene for this game also helps it feel fresh and fun at all times. It's not the hardest thing in the world to set up a simple character mod so long as you can understand some basic code and do some pixel art animations. But even when you're not playing with mods enabled the different characters play really differently from each other but still feel like they all work together. It just feels great to play, modded or not. 5 stars.

183783510.review: Rivals of Aether is an absolute gem in the platform fighter genre that has kept me hooked for hours! The unique mechanics and charming pixel art style create an engaging experience, while the diverse cast of characters ensures no two battles feel the same. What really blew me away is the ability to add custom characters—it's so much fun to dive into the community creations and even try my hand at making my own! The modding tools are user-friendly, and it's amazing to see the creativity that players bring to the game. Whether you're playing competitively or just having a blast with friends, the endless possibilities with custom characters give Rivals of Aether incredible replay value. I'd highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and creative fighting game!

183548192.review:
The main reason to play this game is the workshop mods, where you can pit Obama against good ol' Ron.

Otherwise you'll be fighting against the pantheon of Greek gods in ranked/casual/whatever. Holding one's own online is like trying to floss your teeth with a pool noodle. It's like trying to perform brain surgery while wearing oven mitts. It's like trying to walk on a tightrope wearing high heels. It's like being stared down by Mount Rushmore. Trying to play online is like a liminal purgatory, where your desire to play the game and urge to alt+f4 are in a tug of war. It's like loading up an online game with workshop enabled, and the opponent chooses Cosmic Ronald McDonald. It's like eating pure capsaicin crystals. It might as well suspend your character in animation while your opponent dances circles around you and sings Kumbaya.

Anyway, cool game. Fun to play with friends.
